comments:
CDT 2.0.0.200404281729
Eclipse 200404281424

I consistently receive out of memory exceptions when running 2 large searches
concurrently.  Each search failed and only returned partial results.

The system was running RedHat Enterprise Linux 3.0 and had over 2 GB of RAM.

1220 files in the workspace
5285 expected search results

While this is a use-case we would like to support, I am unsure as to how we 
are going to be able to do this in 2.0.  You could probably even reproduce it 
on a smaller project just with lots of includes into system headers (iostream, 
windows.h, string, etc.)  If a complex set of headers are being parsed by 
different clients at the same time, all bets are off as to whether or not we 
will run out of memory, irregardless of how many optimizations I put in.  

At some point a requirement has to come down from on high telling us what the 
break-even point for this release is regarding these use cases.  Incomplete 
results, to me, seem inevitable.  Handling the OutOfMemoryException properly 
and making sure that the user can continue working after it is the only thing 
we can do.  

I'm not triaging this until we determine whether or not it really fits into 
2.0.
Severity should be raised to at least "major".

This is not just a CDT problem - it is an Eclipse wide problem. I get 
OutOfMemory on JDT searches all the time - always coming out of 
org.eclipse.core.runtime. The CDT currently has handling for OutOfMemory 
errors, so we'll have to keep an eye on this one as builds go by and see if it 
doesn't resolve itself.
Is there a defect for Eclipse tracking this issue?

Ok, forget concurrent searches - large, single searches appear to have problems
by themselves...


Additional observations:


Standard memory configuration:

Windows:
A single search took 14 minutes of 100% CPU usage. Once the CPU usage calmed
down, the progress dialog remained open, results stopped populating the Search
view and the progress info in the bottom right corner remained.

Linux:
A single search took 14 minutes of 100% CPU usage. An error message popped up
while the search view was being populated and indicated that an internal error
occurred "Out of memory".


(-Xmx512m) Configuration:

Windows:
A single search died after 9 minutes and the error "Error: Search results view:
Error" appeared and the .log file contained the following:

Linux:
A single search took 15 minutes of 100% CPU usage. An error message popped up
while the search view was being populated and indicated that an internal error
occurred "Out of memory".


Please note, the number of expected search results noted above is incorrect; it
should be closer to 11000.

Moving to 2.0.1.  We are targeting 2.0.1 as the release to improve parser 
performance and memory usage.

With Eclipse 3.0, concurrent searches seem to be a bit of an oxymoron, since 
the last search to start gains control of the Search Results View and clobbers 
the other one.  Since we can't get the expected behaviour in the 2.0.1 
timeframe, I am moving this defect off to Future.  

We have made considerable progress in improving performance and footprint of 
the parser; once we have proper support from the Platform we should be able to 
handle concurrent searches well.

Eclipse no longer supports concurrent searches.
Marking as INVALID.
